canonical_explanation.text: Health is a state of complete physical, mental, and social well-being, not merely the absence of disease. Disease literally means 'dis-ease' or being uncomfortable. Diseases can be broadly classified as acute (short duration, e.g., common cold) and chronic (long duration, e.g., tuberculosis). Based on causes, diseases are infectious (caused by pathogens like bacteria, viruses, fungi, protozoa, and worms and can spread from person to person) or non-infectious (caused by internal factors and do not spread). Infectious diseases spread through air (droplet infection), water, food, direct contact, and vectors (animals that carry pathogens, e.g., mosquitoes spreading malaria). The immune system defends the body against pathogens through barriers (skin, mucus) and the immune response (white blood cells, antibodies). Treatment involves killing the pathogen (antibiotics for bacteria) or reducing symptoms. Prevention is better than cure and includes vaccination, personal hygiene, clean water, proper sanitation, and vector control.
rules: Health is physical, mental, and social well-being — not just absence of disease.
Acute diseases last for a short time; chronic diseases last for a long time.
Infectious diseases are caused by microorganisms (pathogens) and can spread.
Non-infectious diseases are caused by internal factors and do not spread.
Pathogens include bacteria, viruses, fungi, protozoa, and worms.
Infectious diseases spread through air, water, food, direct contact, and vectors.
Antibiotics work against bacteria but NOT against viruses.
Vaccination provides long-term immunity by training the immune system.
The immune system has a first line (skin, mucus) and second line (WBCs, antibodies) of defence.
Prevention methods: hygiene, clean water, vaccination, balanced diet, vector control.

questions.question_text: According to the WHO definition, health is:

options.text: A state of complete physical, mental, and social well-being
Being able to go to work every day

questions.explanation_correct: According to the World Health Organization (WHO), health is defined as a state of complete physical, mental, and social well-being, and not merely the absence of disease or infirmity. This definition recognizes that health encompasses more than just physical fitness.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Simply being free from disease or being able to work does not mean a person is healthy. Health requires well-being in all three dimensions — physical, mental, and social.

questions.question_text: The word 'disease' literally means:

options.text: Being uncomfortable or not at ease

questions.explanation_correct: The word 'disease' literally means 'dis-ease', which means being uncomfortable or not at ease. It refers to any condition that disturbs the normal functioning of the body or mind, causing discomfort.
questions.explanation_incorrect: While pain, fever, and infection can be associated with disease, the literal meaning of the word 'dis-ease' is simply 'not at ease' or being uncomfortable.

questions.question_text: Which of the following conditions is necessary for good health?

options.text: Clean environment, proper nutrition, and social equality

questions.explanation_correct: Good health requires multiple conditions including a clean environment, proper nutrition, clean drinking water, social equality, and economic well-being. Health is a holistic concept and depends on many interconnected factors, not just one.
questions.explanation_incorrect: While clean water, nutrition, and exercise are all important, good health requires all these factors and more, including social equality and a clean environment. No single factor alone is sufficient.

questions.question_text: A disease that lasts for a very short period of time is called:
questions.explanation_correct: An acute disease is one that lasts for a very short period of time, typically a few days to weeks. Examples include the common cold, cough, and influenza. They appear suddenly and are usually treatable.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Chronic diseases last for a long time (months to years). Infectious and deficiency diseases are classifications based on cause, not duration. Acute refers specifically to short-duration diseases.

questions.question_text: Which of the following is an example of a chronic disease?
questions.explanation_correct: Tuberculosis (TB) is a chronic disease because it lasts for a long period of time — months to years. It is caused by the bacterium Mycobacterium tuberculosis and affects the lungs. Common cold, cough, and influenza are acute diseases of short duration.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Common cold, cough, and influenza are all acute diseases that last for a short time. Tuberculosis is a chronic disease that persists for a long period and requires prolonged treatment.

questions.question_text: Which of the following is a non-infectious disease?
questions.explanation_correct: High blood pressure (hypertension) is a non-infectious disease because it is not caused by a microorganism and cannot spread from one person to another. It is caused by internal factors such as genetics, diet, and lifestyle.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Malaria (caused by Plasmodium), cholera (caused by Vibrio cholerae), and typhoid (caused by Salmonella typhi) are all infectious diseases caused by microorganisms. Hypertension is non-infectious.

questions.question_text: Which type of pathogen causes AIDS?
questions.explanation_correct: AIDS (Acquired Immunodeficiency Syndrome) is caused by the Human Immunodeficiency Virus (HIV). The virus attacks the immune system, specifically the helper T cells, weakening the body's ability to fight infections.
questions.explanation_incorrect: AIDS is not caused by bacteria, fungi, or protozoa. It is caused specifically by a virus — HIV. This is important because viral infections cannot be treated with antibiotics.

questions.question_text: Malaria is caused by which type of organism?
questions.explanation_correct: Malaria is caused by a protozoan parasite called Plasmodium. It is transmitted to humans through the bite of an infected female Anopheles mosquito. The parasite infects red blood cells, causing cycles of fever and chills.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Malaria is not caused by a virus, bacterium, or fungus. It is specifically caused by the protozoan Plasmodium, which is spread by the female Anopheles mosquito acting as a vector.

questions.question_text: Which of the following diseases is caused by bacteria?
questions.explanation_correct: Tuberculosis (TB) is caused by the bacterium Mycobacterium tuberculosis. It primarily affects the lungs. Common cold is viral, malaria is protozoan, and ringworm is fungal.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Common cold is caused by a virus (rhinovirus). Malaria is caused by a protozoan (Plasmodium). Ringworm is caused by a fungus. Only tuberculosis among these options is a bacterial disease.

questions.question_text: An infectious disease that spreads through the bite of a female Aedes mosquito is:
questions.explanation_correct: Dengue is spread through the bite of an infected female Aedes mosquito (Aedes aegypti). The dengue virus causes high fever, severe headache, joint pain, and skin rashes. Malaria is spread by Anopheles mosquitoes, not Aedes.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Malaria is spread by female Anopheles mosquitoes, not Aedes. Tuberculosis spreads through air (droplets). Cholera spreads through contaminated water. Only dengue is specifically associated with Aedes mosquitoes.

questions.question_text: Which of the following diseases spreads through contaminated water?
questions.explanation_correct: Cholera is a waterborne disease caused by the bacterium Vibrio cholerae. It spreads through contaminated water and causes severe diarrhoea and dehydration. Maintaining clean water supply is essential for its prevention.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Tuberculosis spreads through air (droplet infection). AIDS spreads through blood, sexual contact, and from mother to child. Ringworm spreads through direct contact. Cholera is the waterborne disease.

questions.question_text: Ringworm is caused by:
questions.explanation_correct: Despite its name, ringworm is not caused by a worm. It is a fungal infection of the skin that causes circular, ring-shaped red patches. The fungus grows on the outer layer of the skin and spreads through direct contact or contaminated objects.
questions.explanation_incorrect: The name 'ringworm' is misleading — it is not caused by a worm. It is a fungal skin infection. The ring-shaped appearance of the rash gave it the name, not a worm.

questions.question_text: Antibiotics are effective against:
questions.explanation_correct: Antibiotics are effective only against bacterial infections. They work by blocking biochemical pathways important for bacteria, either killing them or preventing their growth. Antibiotics do NOT work against viruses because viruses use the host cell's machinery.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Antibiotics do not work against viruses (viral infections need antiviral drugs). They are not effective against all types of infections. They do not treat non-infectious diseases. Antibiotics specifically target bacteria.

questions.question_text: Vaccination works by:

options.text: Killing all pathogens in the body immediately
Introducing weakened or killed pathogens to train the immune system
Removing all bacteria from the blood

questions.explanation_correct: Vaccination involves introducing weakened or killed pathogens (or their parts) into the body. This stimulates the immune system to produce antibodies and memory cells without causing the actual disease. If the person later encounters the real pathogen, the immune system can respond quickly.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Vaccines do not kill pathogens directly — they train the immune system. They do not provide nutrients or remove bacteria. They work by creating immunological memory for future protection.

questions.question_text: Why are antibiotics not effective against the common cold?

options.text: Because the common cold is not a disease
Because the common cold is caused by a virus, and antibiotics only work against bacteria
Because antibiotics are too strong for the common cold
Because the common cold goes away on its own

questions.explanation_correct: Antibiotics are not effective against the common cold because it is caused by rhinoviruses. Antibiotics target specific bacterial metabolic pathways that viruses do not have. Since viruses use the host cell's machinery to reproduce, antibiotics cannot affect them.
questions.explanation_incorrect: The common cold is indeed a disease (viral). The issue is not about strength — antibiotics simply cannot target viruses. While the cold often resolves on its own, the question asks why antibiotics don't work against it.

questions.question_text: A disease that spreads through the air via tiny droplets when an infected person sneezes or coughs is most likely:
questions.explanation_correct: Tuberculosis (TB) is an airborne disease that spreads through tiny droplets released when an infected person coughs, sneezes, or talks. The bacteria (Mycobacterium tuberculosis) can remain suspended in the air and be inhaled by others.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Cholera spreads through contaminated water, not air. Malaria spreads through mosquito bites. Kala-azar spreads through sandfly bites. Tuberculosis is the disease that characteristically spreads through airborne droplets.

questions.question_text: Which of the following is the most effective long-term strategy to prevent infectious diseases in a community?

options.text: Vaccination, clean water supply, and proper sanitation

questions.explanation_correct: The most effective long-term strategy for preventing infectious diseases in a community is a combination of mass vaccination programs, ensuring clean water supply, and maintaining proper sanitation. These public health measures address multiple disease transmission routes.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Regular antibiotics can lead to antibiotic resistance. Staying indoors always is impractical. Wearing masks helps but is not sufficient alone. A comprehensive approach with vaccination, clean water, and sanitation is the most effective.

questions.question_text: Which of the following is an example of an organ-specific disease manifestation?
questions.explanation_correct: Tuberculosis bacteria specifically target and damage the lungs, which is an organ-specific manifestation. The bacteria affect the lung tissue, causing cough, blood in sputum, and difficulty breathing. Tiredness, headache, and appetite loss are general symptoms not specific to any organ.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Tiredness, headache, and appetite loss are general symptoms that can occur with many diseases and are not specific to any organ. TB's effect on the lungs is an example of organ-specific disease manifestation.

questions.question_text: The first line of defence in the human body against pathogens includes:

options.text: Skin, mucus membranes, and stomach acid
Only the immune cells in the blood

questions.explanation_correct: The first line of defence includes physical and chemical barriers: the skin (prevents entry of pathogens), mucus membranes (trap pathogens in respiratory and digestive tracts), tears (contain lysozyme), and stomach acid (kills most ingested pathogens).
questions.explanation_incorrect: White blood cells and antibodies are part of the second line (immune response). Vaccination and medication are external interventions. The first line of defence consists of the body's natural barriers.

questions.question_text: An animal that carries a pathogen from an infected person to a healthy person without itself getting the disease is called a:
questions.explanation_correct: A vector is an animal (usually an insect) that carries a pathogen from an infected person to a healthy person without itself getting the disease. Examples include the female Anopheles mosquito (malaria vector) and the female Aedes mosquito (dengue vector).
questions.explanation_incorrect: A host is the organism in which the pathogen lives and multiplies. A parasite lives on or in another organism for nutrition. A carrier is a person who harbours a pathogen. A vector specifically refers to an animal that transmits the pathogen.

questions.question_text: Which of the following statements about acute and chronic diseases is correct?

options.text: Acute diseases always become chronic if untreated
Chronic diseases cause more long-term damage to the body than acute diseases
Acute diseases are always more dangerous than chronic diseases
Chronic diseases last only for a few days

questions.explanation_correct: Chronic diseases cause more long-term damage because they persist for a long time. The prolonged effect on the body leads to drastic weight loss, organ damage, and general poor health. Acute diseases, while uncomfortable, usually resolve quickly with less lasting impact.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Not all acute diseases become chronic. Acute diseases are not always more dangerous — some chronic diseases can be life-threatening. Chronic diseases last for months or years, not just days.

questions.question_text: Which of the following correctly matches the disease with its causative organism?
questions.explanation_correct: Kala-azar (visceral leishmaniasis) is correctly matched with its causative organism — the protozoan Leishmania. It is transmitted through the bite of sandflies.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Typhoid is caused by bacteria (Salmonella typhi), not a virus. Malaria is caused by a protozoan (Plasmodium), not bacteria. AIDS is caused by a virus (HIV), not a fungus. Only option C has the correct match.

questions.question_text:
Assertion: Prevention of diseases is better than their cure.
Reason: Once a disease has occurred, the body may already have suffered significant damage.
Choose the correct option:

options.text: Both assertion and reason are true, and reason is the correct explanation
Both assertion and reason are true, but reason is not the correct explanation
Assertion is true but reason is false
Both assertion and reason are false

questions.explanation_correct: Both the assertion and reason are true, and the reason correctly explains the assertion. Prevention is better than cure because once a disease occurs, the body suffers damage, treatment takes time and resources, and some diseases may cause permanent damage or death.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Both statements are true and the reason does explain why prevention is preferred. Once a disease has occurred, there is always some damage to the body, which is why preventing the disease in the first place is the better approach.

questions.question_text: Which of the following factors does NOT directly affect our health?
questions.explanation_correct: The colour of a house does not directly affect health. Clean water prevents waterborne diseases, proper nutrition maintains body functions, and social environment impacts mental health. Health depends on physical, biological, and social conditions, not superficial factors like colour.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Clean water, nutrition, and social environment all directly impact health. The colour of a house has no direct bearing on physical, mental, or social well-being.

questions.question_text: HIV primarily attacks which cells of the immune system?
questions.explanation_correct: HIV primarily attacks helper T-cells (CD4+ T lymphocytes) of the immune system. As these cells are destroyed, the immune system weakens progressively, making the person vulnerable to various opportunistic infections. This condition is called AIDS.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Red blood cells are attacked by the malaria parasite, not HIV. Platelets are involved in blood clotting. Nerve cells are not the primary target of HIV. HIV specifically targets helper T-cells of the immune system.

questions.question_text: Which of the following is NOT a method of preventing infectious diseases?
questions.explanation_correct: Eating junk food regularly does NOT prevent infectious diseases; in fact, poor nutrition weakens the immune system and makes a person more susceptible to infections. Vaccination, personal hygiene, and clean water are all effective prevention methods.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Vaccination, personal hygiene, and clean water are all valid prevention methods. Eating junk food provides poor nutrition, weakening the immune system rather than preventing disease.

questions.question_text: A person has been suffering from fever that comes every 48 hours with severe chills. Which disease is this most likely?
questions.explanation_correct: Periodic fever recurring every 48 hours with severe chills is characteristic of malaria, caused by Plasmodium. The cyclical fever occurs because the parasites multiply inside red blood cells and burst them periodically, releasing toxins.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Typhoid causes continuous high fever, not cyclical. Cholera causes severe diarrhoea, not cyclical fever. Tuberculosis causes persistent cough and low-grade fever. Only malaria is known for its characteristic periodic fever with chills.

questions.question_text: Edward Jenner's contribution to medicine was the development of:
questions.explanation_correct: Edward Jenner developed the first vaccine in 1796 by using cowpox material to provide immunity against smallpox. He observed that milkmaids who had contracted cowpox were immune to smallpox, leading to the concept of vaccination.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Alexander Fleming discovered antibiotics (penicillin). Louis Pasteur developed the germ theory. Anton van Leeuwenhoek improved the microscope. Jenner specifically developed the first vaccine.

questions.question_text: A disease caused by a pathogen that enters the body and targets a specific organ is called:
questions.explanation_correct: When a pathogen enters the body and affects a specific organ (like TB bacteria affecting the lungs or hepatitis virus affecting the liver), it is called an organ-specific infectious disease. The pathogen targets specific tissues based on the point of entry and its own biology.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Deficiency diseases are caused by lack of nutrients. Degenerative diseases involve gradual deterioration. Allergic diseases are immune responses to harmless substances. Organ-specific infectious diseases are caused by pathogens targeting particular organs.

questions.question_text: Typhoid fever is caused by Salmonella typhi. This pathogen enters the body through:
questions.explanation_correct: Salmonella typhi enters the body through contaminated food and water. The bacteria multiply in the intestine and spread to other organs through the blood. Proper hygiene, clean water, and vaccination (typhoid vaccine) help prevent it.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Typhoid does not spread through mosquitoes (that's malaria/dengue), air droplets (that's TB), or skin contact (that's ringworm). It is a food-borne and waterborne disease.

questions.question_text: Which of the following helps in preventing malaria?

options.text: Using mosquito nets and eliminating stagnant water

questions.explanation_correct: Since malaria is transmitted by the bite of female Anopheles mosquitoes, prevention involves avoiding mosquito bites (using nets, repellents) and eliminating mosquito breeding grounds (stagnant water where mosquitoes lay eggs).
questions.explanation_incorrect: Boiling water prevents waterborne diseases like cholera. Hand washing prevents contact-spread diseases. Vitamins help general health but don't prevent malaria. Controlling mosquitoes is the key to malaria prevention.

questions.question_text: Why do people living in overcrowded and poorly ventilated areas have a higher risk of infectious diseases?

options.text: Close proximity and poor air quality facilitate easy spread of airborne pathogens

questions.explanation_correct: Overcrowded areas with poor ventilation allow airborne pathogens to spread easily from one person to another. Close proximity means infected droplets can quickly reach others, and stagnant air means pathogens remain in the environment longer.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Eating more food, exercising less, or sleeping more are not direct factors in the spread of infectious diseases in overcrowded areas. The key factor is the ease of pathogen transmission due to close proximity and poor air quality.

questions.question_text: Health means only the absence of disease in the body.
questions.explanation_correct: This statement is false. Health is not merely the absence of disease. According to the WHO, health is a state of complete physical, mental, and social well-being. A person can be free from disease but still not be healthy if they are under mental stress or social problems.
questions.explanation_incorrect: The statement is false. Health encompasses physical, mental, and social well-being, not just being disease-free.

questions.question_text: Antibiotics can cure viral infections like the common cold.
questions.explanation_correct: This statement is false. Antibiotics work only against bacterial infections. They are ineffective against viruses because viruses use the host cell's machinery for reproduction and do not have their own metabolic pathways that antibiotics can target.
questions.explanation_incorrect: The statement is false. Antibiotics cannot cure viral infections. The common cold is caused by a virus and will not respond to antibiotic treatment.

questions.question_text: Malaria is caused by bacteria and spreads through contaminated water.
questions.explanation_correct: This statement is false on both counts. Malaria is caused by a protozoan (Plasmodium), not bacteria. It spreads through the bite of an infected female Anopheles mosquito, not through contaminated water.
questions.explanation_incorrect: The statement is false. Malaria is caused by the protozoan Plasmodium and is transmitted by mosquito bites, not by contaminated water.

questions.question_text: Vaccination introduces weakened pathogens into the body to trigger an immune response.
questions.explanation_correct: This statement is true. Vaccines contain weakened (attenuated) or killed pathogens, or parts of pathogens. When introduced into the body, they stimulate the immune system to produce antibodies and memory cells without causing the actual disease.
questions.explanation_incorrect: The statement is true. Vaccination works by introducing weakened or killed forms of pathogens to train the immune system to recognize and fight the real pathogen in the future.

questions.question_text: High blood pressure and diabetes are examples of infectious diseases.
questions.explanation_correct: This statement is false. High blood pressure (hypertension) and diabetes are non-infectious diseases. They are not caused by microorganisms and cannot spread from one person to another. They are caused by internal factors such as genetics, diet, and lifestyle.
questions.explanation_incorrect: The statement is false. Both hypertension and diabetes are non-infectious (non-communicable) diseases caused by internal body factors, not by pathogens.

questions.question_text: The principle of immunization is based on the memory of the immune system.
questions.explanation_correct: This statement is true. Immunization works because the immune system has memory. When exposed to a pathogen (through vaccination), the immune system creates memory cells. If the same pathogen enters again, these memory cells quickly produce antibodies, providing faster and stronger protection.
questions.explanation_incorrect: The statement is true. Immune memory is the fundamental principle behind vaccination. Memory cells 'remember' the pathogen and mount a rapid response upon re-exposure.

questions.question_text: Diseases that last for a long period of time are called ___ diseases.
questions.explanation_correct: Chronic diseases persist for a long time — months to years or even a lifetime. Examples include tuberculosis, diabetes, and heart disease. They contrast with acute diseases, which are short-lived.
questions.explanation_incorrect: The correct answer is 'chronic'. Acute diseases are short-lived. Chronic diseases last for a long period and often cause lasting damage to the body.

questions.question_text: The protozoan that causes malaria is called ___.
questions.explanation_correct: Plasmodium is the protozoan parasite that causes malaria. It is transmitted to humans through the bite of an infected female Anopheles mosquito. The most dangerous species is Plasmodium falciparum.
questions.explanation_incorrect: The correct answer is 'Plasmodium'. It is a protozoan (not a bacterium or virus). Plasmodium specifically infects red blood cells and causes the characteristic periodic fever of malaria.

questions.question_text: An organism that carries a pathogen from one host to another is called a ___.
questions.explanation_correct: A vector is an organism (usually an insect) that transmits a pathogen from an infected person to a healthy person. Examples include mosquitoes (for malaria and dengue) and sandflies (for kala-azar).
questions.explanation_incorrect: The correct answer is 'vector'. A host is where the pathogen lives. A carrier is a person harbouring the pathogen. A vector is specifically the organism that transmits the disease agent.

questions.question_text: Medicines that block the metabolic pathways of bacteria and kill them are called ___.
questions.explanation_correct: Antibiotics are medicines that kill or inhibit the growth of bacteria by blocking specific biochemical pathways. Penicillin, the first antibiotic, was discovered by Alexander Fleming in 1928.
questions.explanation_incorrect: The correct answer is 'antibiotics'. They specifically target bacterial metabolic pathways. They do not work against viruses, which use the host cell's machinery.

questions.question_text: According to WHO, health is a state of complete physical, mental, and ___ well-being.
questions.explanation_correct: The WHO defines health as a state of complete physical, mental, and social well-being — not merely the absence of disease. Social well-being includes having a supportive community, economic stability, and social equality.
questions.explanation_incorrect: The correct answer is 'social'. The three dimensions of health according to WHO are physical, mental, and social. All three must be well for a person to be considered truly healthy.

questions.question_text: The female ___ mosquito is the vector for malaria.
questions.explanation_correct: The female Anopheles mosquito transmits the malaria parasite (Plasmodium) when it bites a human. Only the female mosquito bites because it needs blood for egg development. The Aedes mosquito, by contrast, transmits dengue.
questions.explanation_incorrect: The correct answer is 'Anopheles'. The Aedes mosquito transmits dengue, not malaria. It is specifically the female Anopheles mosquito that is the vector for malaria.

questions.question_text: Which of the following diseases is caused by a helminth (worm)?
questions.explanation_correct: Ascariasis is caused by the helminth (roundworm) Ascaris lumbricoides. It is an intestinal infection spread through contaminated soil and food. Helminth infections are common in areas with poor sanitation.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Malaria is caused by a protozoan. Tuberculosis is caused by a bacterium. Dengue is caused by a virus. Only ascariasis is caused by a worm (helminth).

questions.question_text: Which principle of treatment focuses on killing the disease-causing organism in the body?

options.text: Treatment aimed at reducing the effects of disease
Treatment aimed at the cause — killing the pathogen

questions.explanation_correct: One principle of treatment is to target and kill the causative organism. Antibiotics for bacterial infections and antifungals for fungal infections work on this principle. They target specific metabolic pathways of the pathogen to eliminate it from the body.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Symptomatic treatment and rest address symptoms but do not kill the pathogen. Option C specifically refers to targeting the cause of the disease by eliminating the pathogen.

questions.question_text: Peptic ulcers were traditionally thought to be caused by stress, but are now known to be caused by:
questions.explanation_correct: Peptic ulcers are now known to be caused by the bacterium Helicobacter pylori. This was a landmark discovery showing that even conditions previously attributed to lifestyle could have an infectious cause. The discovery earned the Nobel Prize in 2005.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Peptic ulcers are not caused by viruses, fungi, or protozoa. The bacterium Helicobacter pylori was identified as the primary cause, which can be treated with antibiotics.

questions.question_text: Which of the following is an example of a public health measure to prevent diseases?

options.text: Providing clean drinking water and proper sewage disposal in communities
Using antibiotics as a preventive measure

questions.explanation_correct: Providing clean drinking water and proper sewage disposal are essential public health measures. They prevent waterborne diseases like cholera and typhoid at the community level. These are more effective than individual measures alone.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Regular painkillers only mask symptoms. Avoiding physical activity is harmful. Using antibiotics preventively can lead to resistance. Clean water and proper sanitation are genuine public health measures.

questions.question_text: AIDS can spread through which of the following means?

options.text: Sharing food with an infected person
Sharing needles with an infected person
Shaking hands with an infected person

questions.explanation_correct: AIDS (caused by HIV) can spread through sharing contaminated needles, unprotected sexual contact, contaminated blood transfusion, and from an infected mother to her child during pregnancy or breastfeeding. It does NOT spread through casual contact, sharing food, or mosquito bites.
questions.explanation_incorrect: HIV does not spread through sharing food, mosquito bites, or shaking hands. These are common misconceptions. The virus requires direct contact with infected blood or body fluids for transmission.

questions.question_text: Diseases that are caused by microorganisms and can spread from an infected person to a healthy person are called ___ diseases.
questions.explanation_correct: Infectious (or communicable) diseases are caused by pathogenic microorganisms such as bacteria, viruses, fungi, or parasites, and can be spread from one person to another directly or indirectly. Examples include tuberculosis, malaria, and cholera.
questions.explanation_incorrect: The correct answer is 'infectious'. These are also called communicable diseases. Non-infectious diseases, in contrast, cannot spread from person to person.
